verses.text: As He was passing by, He saw a man who had been blind from birth.
verses.comment: Jesus notices the man proactively, indicating divine initiative in healing and mercy.

verses.text: His disciples asked Him, 'Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?'
verses.comment: The disciples reflect the common Jewish belief that suffering comes from personal or inherited sin.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Neither this man nor his parents sinned, but this happened so that the works of God might be revealed in him.'
verses.comment: Jesus refutes the assumption that suffering is always due to sin, and points to God’s providence and mysterious plan.

verses.text: 'We must work the works of Him who sent Me while it is day; night is coming, when no one can work.'
verses.comment: Jesus underlines the urgency of His mission and aligns His ministry with the Father who sent Him.

verses.text: 'While I am in the world, I am the light of the world.'
verses.comment: A clear Christological statement; Jesus identifies Himself as the true light fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy about the coming light for the nations (Isa. 9:2).

verses.text: After He said these things, He spit on the ground, made some mud with the saliva, and applied it to the man’s eyes.
verses.comment: The use of physical elements in the miracle demonstrates a sacramental principle: God uses material means to convey grace.

verses.text: 'Go,' He told him, 'wash in the pool of Siloam' (which means 'Sent'). So he went, washed, and came back seeing.
verses.comment: Obedience connects the man’s faith with healing. The pool's name, 'Sent', echoes Jesus as the One sent from the Father.

verses.text: His neighbors and those who had seen him begging before said, 'Isn’t this the man who used to sit and beg?'
verses.comment: The man’s transformation is evident to all around him.

verses.text: Some said, 'He is the one.' Others said, 'No, but he is like him.' But he kept saying, 'I am he.'
verses.comment: The man’s repeated affirmation signals the reality of the miracle and mirrors the 'I am' sayings of Jesus, suggesting a deeper spiritual identity.

verses.text: So they asked him, 'Then how were your eyes opened?'
verses.comment: The focus turns to the method and the identity of the healer.

verses.text: He replied, 'The man called Jesus made mud, applied it to my eyes, and told me, “Go to Siloam and wash.” So I went and washed, and I received my sight.'
verses.comment: The healed man gives a simple testimony of obedience leading to healing.

verses.text: Then they asked him, 'Where is He?' He said, 'I do not know.'
verses.comment: Jesus often withdraws after a miracle, emphasizing humility and the mystery of His identity.

verses.text: They brought the man who had been blind to the Pharisees.
verses.comment: The matter is brought to religious authorities, setting up a legal inquiry.

verses.text: Now it was a Sabbath day when Jesus made the mud and opened his eyes.
verses.comment: Jesus performs another healing on the Sabbath, challenging legalistic interpretations of the law.

verses.text: Then the Pharisees also asked him again how he had received his sight. He said to them, 'He put mud on my eyes, and I washed, and I see.'
verses.comment: The emphasis on the procedure highlights both physical and ritual elements.

verses.text: Therefore, some of the Pharisees said, 'This man is not from God, because He does not keep the Sabbath.' But others said, 'How can a sinner perform such signs?' And there was division among them.
verses.comment: Division arises about Jesus’ identity. Miraculous signs challenge rigid interpretations of the Sabbath.

verses.text: They said again to the blind man, 'What do you say about Him, since He opened your eyes?' He said, 'He is a prophet.'
verses.comment: Calling Jesus a prophet connects Him to the Old Testament expectation of a prophetic Messiah.

verses.text: The Judean leaders still did not believe that he had been blind and received his sight until they summoned the parents of the man who had received his sight.
verses.comment: The authorities seek further evidence, highlighting skepticism towards miracles.

verses.text: They asked them, 'Is this your son, who you say was born blind? How then does he now see?'
verses.comment: The investigation expands to the man's family.

verses.text: His parents answered, 'We know that this is our son and that he was born blind.'
verses.comment: They confirm the miracle's authenticity.

verses.text: 'But how he now sees, we do not know; nor do we know who opened his eyes. Ask him; he is of age. He will speak for himself.'
verses.comment: The parents distance themselves, likely out of fear. Compare to John 12:42.

verses.text: His parents said these things because they were afraid of the Judean leaders, for the leaders had already agreed that anyone who confessed Jesus as the Messiah would be put out of the synagogue.
verses.comment: Expulsion from the synagogue shows the social risk of acknowledging Jesus as Messiah.

verses.text: That is why his parents said, 'He is of age; ask him.'
verses.comment: This emphasizes the cost of discipleship and personal responsibility in declaring Christ.

verses.text: So they called the man who had been blind a second time and said to him, 'Give glory to God! We know that this man is a sinner.'
verses.comment: 'Give glory to God' is a customary solemn charge to tell the truth. They presume Jesus’ guilt.

verses.text: He replied, 'Whether He is a sinner I do not know. One thing I do know: I was blind and now I see.'
verses.comment: Simple testimony to a real change, foreshadowing Christian witness throughout Church history.

verses.text: Then they asked him, 'What did He do to you? How did He open your eyes?'
verses.comment: Repetition underlines their disbelief and desire for contradiction.

verses.text: He answered, 'I already told you, and you did not listen. Why do you want to hear it again? Do you also want to become His disciples?'
verses.comment: The healed man grows in boldness and sows the seeds of discipleship—implying following Jesus is not merely assent, but a life-commitment.

verses.text: At this they hurled insults at him and said, 'You are this man’s disciple, but we are disciples of Moses.'
verses.comment: The contrast is set between following Moses and the new covenant revealed in Christ.

verses.text: 'We know that God has spoken to Moses, but for this man, we do not know where He is from.'
verses.comment: They confess their ignorance of Jesus’ heavenly origin, though Jesus repeatedly revealed it.

verses.text: The man answered, 'That is remarkable! You do not know where He is from, yet He opened my eyes.'
verses.comment: The healed man highlights the leaders’ blindness to the works of God manifest in Christ.

verses.text: 'We know that God does not listen to sinners, but if anyone is God-fearing and does His will, He listens to him.'
verses.comment: He appeals to Old Testament teaching: God listens to the righteous.

verses.text: 'Never since the world began has it been heard that anyone opened the eyes of a man born blind.'
verses.comment: Old Testament prophecy (Isaiah 35:5) foresaw the healing of the blind as a mark of the Messiah’s kingdom.

verses.text: 'If this man were not from God, He could do nothing.'
verses.comment: Common sense and faith converge: miraculous power testifies to Jesus’ divine sending.

verses.text: They answered him, 'You were completely born in sins, and are you teaching us?' And they cast him out.
verses.comment: Pride and spiritual blindness block acceptance of truth. 'Cast out' foreshadows persecution of the faithful.

verses.text: Jesus heard that they had cast him out, and when He found him, He said, 'Do you believe in the Son of Man?'
verses.comment: ‘Son of Man’ is a messianic, divine title from Daniel 7:13–14, showing Jesus' self-understanding as the Savior-judge.

verses.text: He answered, 'And who is He, Lord, that I may believe in Him?'
verses.comment: Eagerness to believe shows openness and cooperation with God's grace—a theme in spiritual growth.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'You have seen Him. In fact, He is the one speaking with you.'
verses.comment: A direct self-revelation—Jesus identifies Himself as the object of faith, paralleling earlier 'I am' declarations.

verses.text: He said, 'Lord, I believe,' and he worshiped Him.
verses.comment: The man recognizes Jesus’ divinity and worships Him. This act of worship is significant: only God is to be worshipped (see Matt. 14:33).

verses.text: Jesus said, 'For judgment I have come into this world, that those who do not see may see, and those who see may become blind.'
verses.comment: Jesus' coming divides humanity: spiritual vision is given to the humble, but the proud are blinded.

verses.text: Some of the Pharisees near Him heard this, and said to Him, 'Are we also blind?'
verses.comment: Their question ironically exposes their spiritual arrogance.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'If you were blind, you would not have sin. But now that you say, “We see,” your sin remains.'
verses.comment: True knowledge brings responsibility. Claiming to see, but refusing to accept the truth, leaves one in sin. Genuine humility, rather than reliance on self, is the path to true spiritual vision.
